comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: It's still there, restored quite recently: This was the largest telescope in the world for 70 years.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Built in 1845, it had obviously been there a while when this photo was taken, judging from the ivy covered walls.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: What an incredible sight, great old picture.

comment.author: 78381216@N00
comment._content: . . . and heres one taken in August 2012, of the restored telescope!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here it is on the OS 25" map. And in Bing maps more recently.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
A lengthy letter to the Times , reproduced in Freeman's on Apr 29 1842, which goes into great detail about the construction of the telescope, concludes:
The foundry is not many feet from Birr Castle, the residence in Ireland of the Earl of Rosse, and, with the exception of the crucibles ... all the apparatus employed on this interesting occasion (the steam-engine itself included) was made in the workshops adjoining the castle, under the earl's immediate direction, by workmen train and instructed by himself

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: A drawing of the telescope which appeared in The Graphic, March 19, 1892

comment.author: 32149975@N07
comment._content: Great photo! I went there on a visit with our astronomy club at college, one of the things that struck me was that he had this built in one of the places in the country with the fewest cloud free days!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I wonder if the bearded bloke in the photo is Dr Otto Boeddicker? By the 1880s, newspaper reports of observations made using the telescope all seem to quote him.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Oooh, so maybe not Lawrence Parsons then! Shakes fist at Wikipedia (in a non-threatening fashion) for not having a photo of Dr Otto.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] On second thoughts, it can't be Boeddicker, because in 1892 his beard is black (unless he dyed it specially for his appearance in The Graphic) Boeddicker Photo ... but it could be Coughlan or Birmingham (although perhaps too well dressed to be either of them) but not Walsh. Definitely not Walsh.

comment.author: 65379774@N02
comment._content:
Michael Tubridy (flute player with the Chieftains) was the Structural Engineer on the restoration in 1998/99.The old mirror was replaced and is on display .The Parsons
 family were  amazing, as  can be seen after a trip to Birr Castle.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Is there a connection with the Grubb Telescope Company of Dublin? In Newcastle upon Tyne the company traded until 1985. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_Howard_Grubb,_Parsons_and_Co Charles Algernon Parsons, the youngest son of the famous astronomer William Parsons, 3rd Earl of Rosse. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Algernon_Parsons

comment._content: Stunning device! Must visit that.

Ralph Copeland also could fit the bill. www.flickr.com/photos/57442878@N08/5766002059/in/set-7215... I let my beard grow too much in the 1990s. It became too difficult to tie the knot in a necktie.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
This just in from John C McConnell:
... The man with the beard is the Fourth Earl of Rosse. Copeland was only there from 1871-74 and then moved to Dunsink after which he was astronomer to the Earl of Crawford (1876) and then Astronomer Royal for Scotland 1889. I have attached an image from my Flickr set on Birr Castle which shows both the Fourth Earl and Dr Boeddicker so there's little doubt! Also I'm pretty sure the Fourth Earl would have attended to William Lawrence personally...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
